title: The one book you should read this summer
text:
The Guardian quoted George Orwell when reviewing The Overstory and his lament that “Artists of any consequence can never be persuaded into the Socialist fold.” In the absence of Wayne Swan trying his hand at fiction – he blessed us with Postcode: The Splintering of a Nation in 2005 – then this book on the “wisdom of trees” is the best we’ve got.

The Overstory laments our excessive consumption but have you tried getting a vacuum cleaner fixed? DragonImages

It has plenty to offer on the long-term benefits of challenging professional orthodoxy and even a few tips on managing household expenditure. “Her budget is blessedly free of those two core expenses, entertainment and status,” Powers tells us about one of the main characters, Patricia Westerford.

But the central point is that the modern economy is yet to find an accommodation with the natural world, a failure that may ultimately condemn us humans – the trees will survive as they are apparently smarter.

The book is also a rebuke on the idea of consumption being the “sole end and purpose” of economic activity, as Adam Smith told us in 1776. This radical idea of buying less stuff, or at least appearing to, is the modern mantra for the eco-conscious. But it’s not that easy as I’ve recently discovered.

When my kids ask what I did to stem climate change, I’ll tell them I tried to get the vacuum fixed.

Have you tried getting something fixed these days? Short of being an electrical engineer the idea of keeping consumer goods beyond a few years is impossible. Take my Dyson vacuum cleaner – a purchase that provided both entertainment and status. It’s headed for landfill as $700 does not buy you a conveniently located service centre.

Rather in Sydney, it’s a 50-minute drive to an industrial park only open between 8:30am and 4:30pm on weekdays. That’s a stretch for us wage slaves, but I did convince my wife’s aunt she would benefit from a voyage of discovery to Sydney’s Taren Point.

Advertisement

Those repairs lasted a week and then I did what any man who appreciates a clean floor would do – outlaid $199 for a new one. It’s not a Dyson so will have to be hidden from public view.

Ditto the coffee machine, which lasted five years but is also on its way to landfill as there’s no one around to fix it. But don’t worry, when my kids ask what I did to stem climate change, I’ll tell them I tried to get the vacuum fixed and hand them a copy of The Overstory.
description: It's not fair dinkum fiction, but The Overstory, by Richard Powers, has plenty of lessons for us wage slaves.
